Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing an Energy Technology Associate Degree Program to Meet Employer Needs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Local, regional and national energy providers have a critical and long-term need for highly qualified substation and relay technicians to support the sensitive components of the national grid. This project at Lake Sumter State College (LSSC) in Florida is designed to meet this labor force need, with support from Duke Energy and other energy providers, by enhancing an engineering technology specialization in Electrical Substation and Protective Relay Technology (ESPRT). Through a strategic recruitment project, students will be recruited to join a hands-on technician education and training program that will culminate in a paid-summer internship and high skill, high wage employment. The project will focus on widespread dissemination of technical and general industry information that will result in the advancement of this and other similar education and training programs across the country. It will implement strategies to improve the overall science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) culture in the service district of the college. It will also strive to attain much needed racial and gender diversity within faculty and student groups and the energy industry at large. The ESPRT Program leaders will focus on developing an on-going collaboration for program improvement with the Florida ATE Center (FLATE, DUE 1204751), the Advanced Technology Environmental and Energy Center (ATEEC, DUE 1204958), and existing energy industry partners. The college will engage in on-going external and internal research including focus groups, surveys, and advisory board feedback and formal assessments that will result in data-driven decision making and program adjustments.

The ESPRT Program will introduce an academically and technically rigorous next step for students and educators, with both populations attaining knowledge and skills that are instrumental to the success of energy technicians. The primary objectives of the project are to:
(1) Upgrade program course content and materials to reflect current industry practices as identified by industry partners and provide students with knowledge and skills necessary to meet the employment needs of industry for a highly skilled, advanced technology energy workforce for today and the future.
(2) Strengthen partnerships between industry partners, secondary educational institutions, and post-secondary educational entities to ensure that all stakeholders are working collaboratively to meet this existing, substantial workforce need.
(3) Inform targeted populations about careers in energy systems protection and control, resulting in a pipeline of secondary school students for future ESPRT Program cohort groups.
(4) Recruit and enroll no less than 20 students (with a particular emphasis on students from underrepresented racial and/or gender groups) into the ESPRT Program for each enrollment period.
(5) Focus on student retention, student completion, student placement, and workforce needs by placing ESPRT Program students in internships with energy partners and other energy companies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project outcomes addressed in this report include:

  • Upgrade program course content and materials,
  • Strengthen partnerships to meet industry needs,
  • Inform targeted populations about careers that would benefit from the ESPRT Program,
  • Recruit and enroll 20 students (with emphasis from underrepresented racial and/or gender groups) into the ESPRT Program for each enrollment period, and
  • Place ESPRT Program students in internships with energy partners and other energy companies by focusing on student retention, student completion, student placement, and workforce needs.

 

Upgrade Course Content and Materials

All systems put into place within the first three years of initial programming continue to support students learning relevant industry skills identified as important by local industry partners. As Year 4 evaluation activities centered on grant extension activities, there are no updates to add concerning this identified outcome.

 

Strengthen Partnerships to Meet Industry Needs

The program continues to build upon its partnerships to meet this objective. Since the beginning of the program, which saw Year 1 start with one partner, Year 4 finds the program in partnership with four industry partners, who provide approximately three new internships to students each year (pre-pandemic).

 

Inform Targeted Populations About ESPRT Program-related Careers

As with the previous years, the program sponsored a series of events promoting its offerings and a broad awareness of available careers in energy fields. More specifically, the finish of Year 3 saw the completion of two summer camps for area middle and high school students. Year 4 activities included the college hosting the following:

  • Job fair held at the Sumter Center with 13 employers in attendance and 54 students/perspective students and parents attending,
  • FLITE event bringing 6th-12th grade math and science teachers and students to the college for a day of information, speakers, and hands on activities meant to help them explore college-level math and science content,
  • An Energy Day events that brought public school students and teachers to the college for a day of information and hands-on activities with a total of 60 students in attendance, and
  • 2020 awareness event for school counselors that included a day-long program of information, speakers, and activities.

 

Recruit & Enroll 20 Students into ESPRT Program for Each Enrollment Period - Emphasis on Underrepresented Groups in STEM

As with previous years, this recruitment and enrollment, especially of underrepresented groups in STEM,  continues to be the greatest programmatic challenge. While efforts including all female summer camps are expected to increase enrollment of women into the ESPRT program, it is still too early in enrolled camper school progress to determine the extent to which summer camps are having this intended impact.

 

Internship Placement

 

Cumulatively over the grant time period, internship placement for program students has been notably successful. In summer 2016, there were eight students in internships positions. In 2017, there were 12. In 2018, there were 10 students participating in summer internships. In 2019, there were10 students participating in summer internships. Year 4 progress on internships were halted due to COVID. No internships were held In the summer of 2020. Instead, Career Development Services held a virtual speakers series, structured around nine sessions at which speakers from six different companies spoke about related topics. Looking into the program’s post-pandemic future, feedback from program organizers indicates that Career Development Services staff plan to continue to work with partners and students to provide internships each summer. Further outreach will be coordinated through Workforce Development who will continue to work with Admissions and faculty to recruit students, especially in underrepresented groups, into the program. The program will continue to work  with Lake, Sumter, and Marion County schools through existing articulation agreements. Duke Energy and SECO will continue to be part of the leadership team and participate in events and in the hiring of students.
